segments.text: One, two, three, four, testing.
Murray, now you say something.
Hello, hello, I'm here.
This is September the 12th, and I have the pleasure and honor of chatting.
postdoctoral role while I joined the faculty at Cornell.

Dr. Morris Bloodworth, who was head of the department at Texas A&M during those years and who had served on my master's committee, had told me at many professional meetings that it was just a matter of time until he would recruit me back to Texas A&M for faculty.
So after I'd been at Cornell five years,
Dr. Bloodworth came along with a faculty offer.
By that time, I'd developed quite a good feel for Cornell.
Really was uncertain about whether I would be granted tenure there or not, and knew if I was not going to receive tenure, a decision would be a very easy one.
But if I did receive tenure, I actually served on the Cornell faculty as an associate professor for two months back to Texas A&M.
That was probably the hardest professional decision I've ever made.
You can look back even to this day and wonder, I guess, in some respects, whether it was the right decision or not.
Well, a lot of things played into it.
We were about 1,800 miles from my family, and we were 1,000 miles from my wife's family, and they were 1,000 miles apart.
And that made any kind of, well, it took all the vacation that we had in the summer in those days with young children.
We'd spend three weeks vacation, and we'd spend about half of it on the road.
And so that was a strong motivator.
motivating factor.
I did not know whether my wife, who was a native of Wisconsin, whom I met during my PhD years,
more familiar with the soils in the state, and to interact with Dr. Dixon, who preceded me here by about two months.
So we had the same kinds of research interests.
Well, it really developed a bunch.
Carthage and then Chambers County.
I remember down on the Gulf Coast.
And those were all one week stays and seen very extensively.
Those would come during what we call a final field review for the survey of those counties, the soil survey.

So you go to all the parts of the county and you see the major kinds of soils that occur in that environment and discuss all of the different controversies about how to classify them and their uses and limitations and that kind of thing.
That was an extremely fortunate to have that luxury in time, I suppose you'd say, in the first year.
But to this day, I use a lot of slides in teaching the introductory soils course that I got in that first nine months I was here.
And not to mention just the knowledge and appreciation for the variety of soils in the state.
What else did you learn about the people of Texas and their variety?
from those weeks?
I don't know if, of course I grew up in Texas and since I went to A&M I guess you can say I had classmates from all parts of the state.
One of the things when I first began teaching that truly shocked me was the variety in terms of origin of surnames of students I had in class in Texas as compared to New York State.
If you'd asked me offhand, I would have said there would have been a lot greater cultural diversity in the student body at Cornell University than there would be at Texas A&M.
That's not the case.
There's a much, I immediately encountered so many different
from all over Eastern Europe and Germany, and not to mention the Hispanic influence here as compared to New York.
So about the only thing you could say at Cornell, in contrast, would be a much greater Jewish presence among the students at Cornell than here.
I didn't recognize at that time.
I wouldn't have recognized a Jewish surname from any other name.
But I had a lab technician who was quite good at it.
and had some prejudices, so he didn't hesitate to express his feelings about some.
Incidentally, the Jewish students at Cornell were outstanding students in the classroom, exceptional students.
Describe your getting settled into the department.
Where was it, about how many people, who were the key leaders of the department in 1968?
Marsh Bloodworth became head in 1963 and continued in that role until 1979, so he was obviously the kingpin in the department at that time.
Actually, the department probably had more graduate students at that time than it has today.
The faculty was not as large, although Dr. Bloodworth hired his first faculty member, I believe, in 1964 or 5.
And in 1968, counting faculty here and off campus, I believe there were five or six employees in that year alone.
And then continuing through the mid-70s, there was considerable addition to the faculty in terms of breadth of expertise.
in soil science as well as other disciplines.
So that was a period, well, a period for the entire university, but it was a period of very rapid growth for the department.
And I think that was primarily his leadership.

I think almost anybody even today here would tell you that Morris Bloodworth, and as I mentioned, O.D., and maybe Perry, they got the lion's share of the increases that were enjoyed during those early years.
George Kunze had already moved to the graduate college when I got here.
Jack Rockles was soon to become director of Water Resources Institute.
So Jack would have been a leader, but gosh, there were a number of other faculty members.
About how many total in the department?
On campus, probably, and this is a wild guess, I don't know, probably 30, I'm guessing.
What do you think the national reputation of the department was then?
Not very good.
I think you can generally say that for most, but by that time, by that time, recognized as an up-and-coming place.
Because we'd already been,
But at that time, just beginning to see really the takeoff that stemmed from all of those decisions that Dr. Rutter was instrumental in making and bringing to fruition.
So the enrollment was definitely on the upswing, beginning to hire faculty, having a lot of retirements of some
some people who had done, had performed yeoman service, but of an entirely different type than faculty to give you any kind of national presence would give.
Where were y'all located and what were your facilities?
here on campus?
Well, the department's always been in several buildings.
As large as facilities we have now, you'd think we'd be all be in one building, but we are.
At that time, I was housed in the what is now the Butler Building.
It was known then as the Grumman Building, and the building next to it we referred to as the old red brick building, and most of the soils faculty were in that building.
Now that's never housed.
That's over near the system
Yeah, the Butler building is kind of across from the old physics building and the trigon, the military science building.
The one with the big columns in front, you look in that area, you look right into the gravity building.
And the old red brick building, it's no longer red, but it still stands, was immediately next to that one on the northwest, I guess you'd say.
So it would be, in a sense, further up the street toward the Cushing Library at that time.
So we occupied primarily those two buildings.
Shared the State Chemist at that time.
It was in the old Red Vic building.
In fact, it was called the State Chemist building.
But a lot of the soil is back in there.
It was a dungeon.
No air conditioning, no central air in any of those buildings at that time.
All window air conditioning.
Where were the labs that you and other and your colleagues used for your instruction?
Well, the lab that I used was on the first, in the kind of basement, half basement in the old agronomy building.
I mean, it had windows, but it was mostly below ground, half and half.
The man who had been teaching in that position had, well, it really wasn't his first love.
He taught a senior level course before teaching that.
He was known for being reasonably cantankerous.
And then there was a fellow that preceded him whose nickname was Whiskey Jack.
Guys used to talk about finding him inebriated on lab benches.
I would say that basic soils course, which is very important in the entire agricultural activity,

it needed it needed some attention and the lab was oh it was in pitiful shape and and my predecessor was in it through the fall and spring of 1968-69 and my first teaching at Texas A&M was in the summer of 1969 so I had I couldn't I didn't have any access to the facility until he was gone
I think it's fair to say I've never worked harder in my life than I worked at Summit.
As you, during that first year, what kind of advice did anyone give you about being a faculty member here or anything like that?
Did anybody give you any guidelines or rules or?
No, I don't remember being given a lot of advice.
I guess I probably got as much advice from Dean Kunkle as anybody, although I didn't spend a lot of time with Dean Kunkle, but he was always philosophized with you a little bit.
Dr. Potts, of course, was an institution at that time in the College of Agriculture, his associate dean, and I'll have to give him a lot of credit in this sense.
In those first two or three years,

He encouraged me to go to regional teaching workshops and anything that came up that I think he thought would be any kind of help or guidance in teaching, he was very eager to encourage you to take part in it.
Dr. Bloodworth would always support him, but he'd never think about
having somebody look for those kinds of opportunities, Dr. Potts did.
And so he had a major role in getting me out to learn about developments in the technological aspect of the teaching at that time.
And it was extremely supportive.
Within the department, actually the man I followed had been the graduate advisor for the department.
And in addition to teaching the undergraduate course, I almost inherited that role.
And that meant almost from day one, while I didn't have
graduate students myself other than some, well, I did have a few, but very few along.
But basically, I interacted with all of the faculty in that role as graduate advisor.
So I had a lot of opportunity to interact with other faculty members across a pretty, I mean our department represents a wide variety of disciplines.
So I had an opportunity to interact with a lot of people that I wouldn't have otherwise.
What was it, now you were a former student from this department, did that turn out to be an advantage, a disadvantage, or a mixed blessing as you were a young new faculty member?
I was obviously advantaged in getting a job in the first place.
I don't think it had anything to do.
None of the veterans came in to talk down to you?
No, no, I never, no.
A lot of them, so many of us were at the same time.
What did you and your colleagues think were the unspoken, unwritten
guidelines about when you went to work, what you wore, how you did your job.
What did you assume were the guidelines for you as a professional?

Well, I expect most of us thought we ought to be at work at 8 o'clock in the morning, we ought to stay there till 5, and obviously all of us were 12-month employees, so we thought unless it was a holiday or we were on vacation, we should be there.
Now his dress was, I think most of us always wore a tie when we were going to the classroom.
But a lot of the work of faculty in the department has always been field oriented.
So I think it's always been acceptable if you were not in the classroom to dress casually.
And you're, beginning in 69, what were your, what were your responsibilities for courses and so forth in the early years?
What courses were you to teach?
Oh, well, you know, this is, but pretty much throughout my entire career, my major responsibility in teaching has been one course.
It's been the introductory course in soil science.
What number?
Agronomy 301.
Did it have a nickname?
among the students?
Well, I've heard it referred to as Murray Milford's Magical Mystery Hour.
Some of the students went out one year and bought t-shirts and came back in with them on.
They had Milford's clods on the back of their t-shirts.
And this is normally to juniors?
It's a junior level course, but it's taken by anything from sophomores to graduate students.
And probably most of the years I've taught it, it's been maybe more juniors than anything else, but next to that, seniors.
Enrollments ranged all the way from, I guess, when I first started, around 100 students a semester.
We've always taught it fall, spring, and summer.
I've not missed since...
Well, since the summer of 69, I've not missed a summer, fall, or spring to teach that course.
Now, the enrollment went as high as 426.
And I had them all that semester.
Shortly thereafter, we were able to add some faculty.
So there have been a couple of other people who have taught the course.
And this is the basic course for anyone majoring in soil and crop sciences, and what else?
It's been a required course.
Of course, it's required for all the students that are major, but it's been a required course in many other disciplines over the years, not as many today as in the past.
But when I came here, it was required for all students in animal science, recreation, parks,
horticulture, agricultural education, range land ecology management, would have been range science back then.
Plant sciences, strongly recommended in a couple of areas in ag economics, wildlife and fisheries required in part of their programs.
Always had some students from geology, some study in earth science for teaching purposes.
No engineers, no M.E.s?
No agricultural engineering, it was required by agricultural engineers, but none of the others.
As you started out in that course, what were your private guidelines for how you were hoping to do the course?
For you as a teacher, what was your philosophy?
I really don't know all the things that shaped how I put the course together.
I suppose you could say I was strongly influenced by what I found at Cornell when I began teaching there.
The textbook used for the course there was, at that time, called Buckman and Brady.
The textbook is now in its 12th edition, I believe.
It goes back into the 1920s, probably.
And Dr. Brady was the department head, actually.
He moved to the department head when I became a member of the faculty.
But we alternated teaching that course there.
One fellow taught it in the fall, I taught it in the spring, and then we alternated in the summer to teach it.
And this fellow had more experience with that course than I did, but we met together every summer
and went over the content of the laboratory, and there's a laboratory with it.
So we, in effect, redid the laboratory exercises every summer.
And so I had a chance to make inputs into those.
So I guess the content was pretty much shaped to that, although the fellow that I took introductory soils from at Texas A&M was a man named Hank Foth.
F-O-T-H?
F-O-T-H.
He was only at Texas A&M three years when he went to Michigan State, which I believe was his alma mater, and he spent the rest of his career there.
I thought he was an excellent teacher, and subsequently I think Michigan State proved that.
He wrote a textbook as well.
His textbook I got a lot of ideas from, but it was not nearly as
oh, meaty's probably the right term, as the one that we had at Cornell.
So I used, but I took ideas from it.
And that's how we developed the course.
And I would say it's not, as far as the organization and topics treated, it's not changed substantially over the years.
with the big emphasis on behavioral objectives or instructional objectives that was beginning to be a big deal in the late 60s and early 70s.
I totally did instructional objectives, which I'd not done before for it.
Somewhere early on, and do you know right now, I'm not at all sure whether I started doing it at Cornell or not, but I think maybe I did.
Remember, I was on the faculty there from 1963 to 1968.
It was during a period, Vietnam, during a period where I think faculty became very hesitant to say anything controversial to students.
You weren't supposed to.

I'm not, and I'm not honestly not sure when I started doing it, but I started early on to think that in addition to trying to teach subject matter, cognitive and subject matter, the faculty member had about as much responsibility to try to
be a witness to life, philosophize a little bit about life and what it is all about.
So I would always editorialize.
And when I started doing this, I'm not sure, but I did it at Cornell.
I know the idea for doing it was developed there, and I think it probably did.
But so I always tell my classes, first five minutes are mine.
We talk about whatever we want to.
You know, this semester I've already talked about Bonfire.

I've talked about credit cards and their use, talked about alcohol, talked about silver taps being an important tradition, urging to participate, talked about being environmentally aware, take trash out of the classroom, close doors behind you when you go in and out of bed.
So I've done that kind of thing.
Yeah, and I have a final editorial that runs about 25 minutes, which is, that's the only time that I make any overt statement about being a Christian, but I do in that final 25 minutes of class.
And what's been the reaction, you think, over the years?
More favorable comments about the editorials on the course critique questionnaire and anything else.
I guess we'll get somewhere between two and five comments in the vein of
I'll pay my money to take the soil, so I don't care to hear your philosophy.
I've never been bothered by those because I feel like at least once I try, I've pricked them in a pretty sensitive spot.
In all of your teaching, did you have any role models that affected the way you did it?
Probably my mother and dad.
Okay.
bigger role models than anybody.
I come from a family of teachers.
My mother was a teacher.
Her sisters were teachers.
Her brother was a teacher.
So there were four of them.
They were all teachers.
